docblock.description: The file for the Num class
A class of utility methods for PHP numbers (aka, "num")
docblock.long-description: Keep in mind, a number in PHP (and hereafter in this class documentation) is considered to be a (float), (int), or numeric (string).

docblock.description: Returns true if float $a is almost equal to float $b
docblock.long-description:
Floating point numbers should never be compared for equivalence because of the way they are stored internally. They have limited precision, and many numbers numbers that are representable as floating point numbers in base 10 (e.g., 0.1 or 0.7) do not have an exact representation as floating point numbers in base 2.
To test floating point values for equality, an upper bound on the relative error due to rounding is used. This value is known as the machine epsilon, and is the largest acceptable difference in calculations (exclusive).

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the maximum allowed difference (exclusive) (optional;

if omitted defaults to 0.00001)

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $epsilon is not greater than zero

docblock.description: Bounds a value between an upper and/or lower bound (inclusive)
docblock.long-description:
I'll bound $number between a lower an upper bound; greater than or equal to a lower bound; or, less than or equal to an upper bound.
For example:
Num::bound(1, 0); // returns 1 Num::bound(0, 1); // returns 1 Num::bound(-1, null, 2); // returns -1 Num::bound(3, null, 2); // returns 2 Num::bound(2, 1, 3); // returns 2 Num::bound(4, 1, 3); // returns 3

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $number and $lower and/or $upper are not passed

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $lower is passed and not a number

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $upper is passed and not a number

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $upper is not greater than or equal to $lower

docblock.description: Returns $number ceiling-ed to the nearest $multiple
docblock.long-description:
For exampel:
Num::ceilTo(5, 2); // returns 6 Num::ceilTo(15, 10); // returns 20 Num::ceilTo(25, 40); // returns 40

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the multiple to ceil to (optional; if omitted,

defaults to 1 (aka, PHP's native ceil() function))

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $multiple is not greater than zero

docblock.description: Returns $number floor-ed to the nearest $multiple
docblock.long-description:
For example:
Num::floorTo(19, 10); // returns 10 Num::floorTo(0.99, 0.5); // returns 0.5 Num::floorTo(101, 100); // returns 100

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the multiple to floor to (optional; if omitted,

defaults to 1 (aka, PHP's native floor() function))

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $multiple is not greater than zero

docblock.description: Alias for the isInt() method
Alias for the isNumeric() method
Returns true if $number is a valid database id (aka, unsigned int)
docblock.long-description:
A valid id is a positive, non-zero integer that's less than or equal to the maximum value for the unsigned datatype.
For example:
Num::isId('abc'); // returns false Num::isId(1.5); // returns false Num::isId(123); // returns true Num::isId(999999, 'small'); // returns false

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the column datatype name (possible values are

'tiny[int]', 'small[int]', 'medium[int]', 'int[eger]', and 'big[int]')
(case-insensitive) (optional; if omitted, defaults to 'int')

tag.name: return
tag.description: true if the number is a valid database id

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $datatype is not an allowed value

docblock.description: Returns true if $number is an integer or integer string
docblock.long-description:
PHP's native is_int() functions returns false on strings like '23' or '1'. I will evaluate those integer strings to true.
For example:
is_int(1); // returns true Num::isInt(1); // returns true
is_int('1'); // returns false Num::isInt('1'); // returns true

tag.name: return
tag.description: true if $number is an integer or integer string

docblock.description: Returns true if $number is an integer, decimal, fraction, or mixed number
docblock.long-description:
PHP's native is_numeric() method will return false on fractions or mixed numbers. I'll return true.
For example:
is_numeric(2); // returns true self::isNumeric(2); // returns true
is_numeric(1.5); // returns true self::isNumeric(1.5); // returns true
is_numeric("1.5"); // returns true self::isNumeric("1.5"); // returns true
is_numeric("1/2"); // returns false self::isNumeric("1/2"); // returns true
is_numeric("1 1/2"); // returns false self::isNumeric("1 1/2"); // returns true

docblock.description: Returns true if the value is zero
docblock.long-description:
It can be a little tricky to evaluate a variable in PHP as zero. If you use PHP's native empty function, it will consider 0, '0', 0.0, and '0.0' as empty. However, it will also consider false, array(), '' as empty too. If you compare a value to the possible values for zero in PHP over-and-over, it's a pain. I make it easy.
For example:
Num::isZero((int) 0); // returns true Num::isZero((float) 0.0); // returns true Num::isZero("0"); // returns true Num::isZero("0.0"); // returns true
I'm particularly useful when combined with PHP's empty() function.
$a = ! empty(0); // evaluates to false $b = ! empty(0) || Num::isZero(0); // evaluates to true

docblock.description: Returns a normalized value between 0 and 1 (inclusive)
docblock.long-description:
In statistics, it's often helpful to normalize (sometimes referred to as index) values for comparison. For example, for a retailer to compare an item's revenue against its quantity-in-stock, the values must be normalized (otherwise, revenue will likely be in the thousands of dollars and quantity in stock will likely be in the dozens).
If you divide every item's revenue by the maximum revenue of any item, you'll have a normalized value between 1 and 0. If you do the same for quantity-in-stock, you can compare the two values easily.
For example:
Num::normalize(1, 100); // returns 0.01 Num::normalize(50, 100); // returns 0.5 Num::normalize(0, 100); // returns 0 Num::normalize(150, 100); // returns 1

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $max is not greater than zero

docblock.description: Rounds $number to the nearest $multiple
docblock.long-description:
For example:
Num::roundTo(7, 2); // returns 8 Num::roundTo(7, 4); // returns 8 Num::roundTo(7, 8); // returns 8

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the multiple to round to (optional; if omitted,

defaults to 1 (aka, PHP's native round() method))

docblock.description: Returns the numeric value of $var
docblock.long-description:
PHP does not natively support fractions, mixed numbers, or comma-separated values, but I will. Woot!
I use the following rules:
Bools Bools are returns as strictly typed integers.
Integers Integers are returned as strictly typed integers.
Floats Floats are returned as strictly typed integers.
Strings Numeric strings are returned as their strictly typed equivalent (i.e., an integer or float). Numeric strings with commas are returned as their strictly typed equivalents. Fractions and mixed numbers are returns as floats. All other strings return 0.
Arrays Empty arrays return 0, and non-empty arrays return 1.
Objects This method should not be used on objects. However, unlike the native PHP intval() or floatval() methods, I will not raise an error. I will always evaluate objects as 1.
For example:
Num::bool(true); // returns (int) 1 Num::val(1); // returns (int) 1 Num::val('1'); // returns (int) 1 Num::val(1.5); // returns (float) 1.5 Num::val('1.5'); // returns (float) 1.5 Num::val('1 1/2'); // returns (float) 1.5 Num::val('3/2'); // returns (float) 1.5 Num::val('3\2'); // returns (float) 1.5 Num::val('1000'); // returns (int) 1000 Num::val('1,000'); // returns (int) 1000 Num::val('1,000.5'); // returns (float) 1000.5 Num::val('10000'); // returns (int) 10000 Num::val('1,0,0'); // returns 0 Num::val('abc'); // returns 0 Num::val(array()); // returns 0 Num::val(array('foo')); // returns 1 Num::val(new stdClass()); // returns 1

tag.name: see
tag.description: (Pascal MARTIN) (edited to allow back- or forward-slashes in fractions)

tag.name: see
tag.description: (Justin Morgain) (edited to allow leading and trailing zeros in comma-separated numbers)

docblock.description: The file for the Arr class
A class of array (aka, "arr") utility functions
Filters an array by key

tag.name: param
tag.description: the function to call for each key in $arr

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $callback is not a callable function

docblock.description: Filters an array by a key prefix
docblock.long-description: I'll iterate over each key in $array. If the key starts with $prefix, I'll add it to the result array. Array keys are preserved.

docblock.description: Wildcard search for a value in an array
docblock.long-description:
I'll search $haystack for $needle. Unlike PHP's native in_array() method, I'll accept begins-with (e.g., "foo*"), ends-with (e.g., "*foo"), and contains (e.g., "*foo*") wildcard notation.
For example:
Arr::in_array_wildcard('foo', ['foo', 'bar']); // returns true Arr::in_array_wildcard('qux', ['foo', 'bar']); // returns false Arr::in_array_wildcard('fo*', ['foo', 'bar']); // returns true Arr::in_array_wildcard('*oo', ['foo', 'bar']); // returns true Arr::in_array_wildcard('*o*', ['foo', 'bar']); // returns true

tag.name: return
tag.description: true if the needle exists in haystack

docblock.description: Returns true if the array has at least one string key (excluding int strings)
docblock.long-description:
PHP natively treats all arrays as associative arrays. I'll consider an associative array as an array with a string key. Interally, PHP casts string keys containing valid integers to integer type (e.g., "8" will be stored as 8).
For example:
Arr::isAssoc([1, 2, 3]); // returns false Arr::isAssoc(['foo', 'bar', 'baz']); // returns false Arr::isAssoc(['1' => 'foo', 2 => 'bar']); // returns false (PHP casts '1' to 1) Arr::isAssoc(['1' => 'foo', 8 => 'bar']); // returns false (sparse doens't matter) Arr::isAssoc(['1' => 'foo', 'bar' => 'baz']); // returns true

tag.name: return
tag.description: true if the array has a string key (excluding int strings)

docblock.description: Returns true if $key does not exist in $array or $array[$key] is empty

tag.name: param
tag.description:
a flag indicating whether or not zero is

considered empty (optional; if omitted, defaults to true - i.e., the
default behavior of PHP's empty() function )

tag.name: return
tag.description: true if the key exists and its value is not empty

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $isZeroEmpty is not a bool value

docblock.description: Replaces all occurences of $search with $replace in $array's keys
docblock.long-description: I'll return an array with all occurences of $search in the array's keys replaced with the given $replace value (case-insensitive).

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the value being searched for (aka the needle); an

array may be used to designate multiple neeeles

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the replacement value that replaced found $search

values; an array may be used to designate multiple replacements

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $search is not a string or array

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $replace is not a string or array

docblock.description: Sorts an array of associative arrays by a field's value
docblock.long-description:
Oftentimes, you have a 0-indexed array of associative arrays. For example, a SELECT sql query result or a display-friendly data array. I'll sort a 0-based array of associative arrays by a field's value.
For example:
$a = [['foo' => 'c'], ['foo' => 'a'], ['foo' => 'b']]; $b = Arr::usort_field($a, 'foo'); print_r($b); // prints [['foo' => 'a'], ['foo' => 'b'], ['foo' => 'c']]

tag.name: param
tag.description: the array of associative arrays to sort

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the sort order (possible values 'asc[ending]' or

'desc[ending]) (optional; if omitted, defaults to 'asc') (case-insensitive)

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $sort is not the string 'asc[ending]' or 'desc[ending]'

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $array is not an array of arrays with the key $field

docblock.description: Sorts an array of objects using a public property's value

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the object's public property name (may be a magic

public property via the object's __get() method)

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the sort order (possible values 'asc[ending]' or

'desc[ending]) (optional; if omitted, defaults to 'asc') (case-insensitive)

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $sort is not the string 'asc[ending]' or 'desc[ending]'

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $array is not an array of objects with the public property $property

docblock.description: Sorts an array of objects using a method's return value

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the name of the public method to use (may be a "magic"

method via the object's __call() magic method)

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the sort order (possible values 'asc[ending]' or

'desc[ending]) (optional; if omitted, defaults to 'asc') (case-insensitive)

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $sort is not the string 'asc[ending]' or 'desc[ending]'

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $array is not an array of objects with the public property $property

docblock.description: The file for the Str class
The string (aka, "str") utility class
Returns true if $haystack ends with $needle (case-sensitive)
docblock.long-description:
For example:
Str::endsWith('foobar', 'bar'); // returns true Str::endsWith('foobar', 'baz'); // returns false Str::endsWith('foobar', 'BAR'); // returns false Str::endsWith('foobar', ''); // returns false Str::endsWith('', 'foobar'); // returns false

docblock.description: Returns true if $haystack ends with $needle (case-insensitive)
docblock.long-description: Str::endsWith('foobar', 'bar'); // returns true Str::endsWith('foobar', 'baz'); // returns false Str::endsWith('foobar', 'BAR'); // returns true

docblock.description: Alias for the isBool() method
Returns true if $string is a bool string
docblock.long-description:
I'll return true if $string is a bool string like 'true', 'false', 'yes', 'no', 'on' or 'off'. Keep in mind, I only handle strings. I will return false if you test an actual bool value (because it's not a string).
is_bool(true); // returns true Str::is_bool(true); // returns false
is_bool('true'); // returns false Str::isBool('true'); // returns true
is_bool('yes'); // returns false Str::isBool('yes'); // returns true

docblock.description: Returns true if $haystack starts with $needle (case-insensitive)
docblock.long-description:
For example:
Str::iStartsWith('foobar', 'bar'); // returns false Str::iStartsWith('foobar', 'foo'); // returns true Str::iStartsWith('foobar', 'FOO'); // returns true Str::iStartsWith('', 'foobar'); // returns false Str::iStartsWith('foobar', ''); // returns false

tag.name: param
tag.description: str the case-insensitive substring to search for

docblock.description: Returns a random string of $length that follows the charset $rules

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the length of the password (optional; if omitted,

defaults to 8)

tag.name: param
tag.description:
an array of character counts indexed by charset name

(possible charset names are 'lower', 'upper', 'number', 'alpha', and 'symbol')
(optional; if omitted, defaults to ['lower' => 1, 'upper' => 1, 'number' => 1,
'symbol' => 1])

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if a key in $rules is not a valid charset name

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if a value in $rules is not an integer

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if the number of required characters (as defined in the $rules array) exceeds the $length

docblock.description: Returns a random string
docblock.long-description:
For example:
echo Str::rand(8, 'alpha'); // example 'hbdrckso' echo Str::rand(8, ['lower', 'number']); // example 'k987hb54' echo Str::rand(8, ['upper', 'symbol']); // example 'HG!V*X]@'

tag.name: param
tag.description: the length of the string to return

tag.name: param
tag.description:
a string charset name or an array of charset names

(possible values are are 'lower', 'upper', 'alpha' (a combination of 'upper'
and 'lower'), 'number', and 'symbol') (optional; if omitted, defaults to
['alpha', 'number', 'symbol'])

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $charsets is not a string or array

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if a given $charset is not a valid charset

docblock.description: Splits a string on the first alpha character
docblock.long-description:
I'll return an array with two parts. The first element is the string part before the first alpha character, and the second part is everything after and including the first alpha character.
For example:
Str::splitOnFirstAlpha("123"); // returns ["123"] Str::splitOnFirstAlpha("abc"); // returns ["", "abc"] Str::splitOnFirstAlpha("123 abc"); // returns ["123", "abc"] Str::splitOnFirstAlpha("1 2 3 abc"); // returns ["1 2 3 4", "abc"]

docblock.description: Returns true if $haystack starts with $needle (case-sensitive)
docblock.long-description:
For example:
Str::startsWith('foobar', 'bar'); // returns false Str::startsWith('foobar', 'foo'); // returns true Str::startsWith('foobar', 'FOO'); // returns false Str::startsWith('foobar', ''); // returns false Str::startsWith('', 'foobar'); // returns false

docblock.description: Converts a php.ini-like byte notation shorthand to a number of bytes
docblock.long-description:
In the php.ini configuration file, byte values are sote in shorthand notation (e.g., "8M"). PHP's native ini_get() function will return the exact string stored in php.ini and not its integer equivalent. I will return the integer equivalent.
For example:
Str::strtobytes('1K'); // returns 1024 Str::strtobytes('1M'); // returns 1048576 Str::strtobytes('1G'); // returns 1073741824

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $string does not end in 'k', 'm', or 'g'

docblock.description: Returns a string in camel case
docblock.long-description:
For example:
Str::strtocamelcase('Hello world'); // returns "helloWorld" Str::strtocamelcase('H3LLO WORLD!'); // returns "helloWorld" Str::strtocamelcase('hello_world'); // returns "helloWorld"

docblock.description: Truncates $string to a preferred length
docblock.long-description: Str::truncate('Lorem ipsum inum', 8); // returns 'Lorem ipsum...' Str::truncate('Lorem ipsum inum', 8, ''); // returns 'Lorem ip...' Str::truncate('Lorem ipsum inum', 8, ' ', ' >>>'); // returns 'Lorem ipsum >>>'

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the break character (to truncate at exact length set to

empty string or null) (if the break character does not exist in the string,
the string will be truncated at limit) (optional; if omitted, defaults to ' ')

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the padding to add to end of string (optional; if

omitted, defaults to '...')

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $limit is not an integer (or integer string)

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $break is not a string or null

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $pad is not a string or null

docblock.description: The file for the Bool class
A class of boolean (aka, "bool") utility methods
Returns $bool value in the string $format
docblock.long-description:
I'll return a bool value as a true-false, yes-no, or on-off string.
For example:
Bool::booltostr(true); // returns (string) 'true' Bool::booltostr(true, 'yes-no'); // returns (string) 'true' Bool::booltostr(false, 'on-off'); // returns (string) 'off'

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the string format to convert to (possible values are

't[/-]f', true[/-]false', 'y[/-]n', 'yes[/-]no', 'o[/-o]', and 'on[/-]off')
(case-insensitive) (optional; if omitted, defaults to 'true-false')

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $format is not a valid format

docblock.description: Returns the boolean value of $var
docblock.long-description:
PHP's native boolval() function is not available before PHP 5.5, and it does not support the strings 'yes', 'no', 'on', or 'off'.
I follow the following rules:
Strings The strings "yes", "true", "on", or "1" are considered true, and the strings "no", "false", "off", or "0" are considered false (case-insensitive). Any other non-empty string is true.
Numbers The numbers 0 or 0.0 are considered false. Any other number is considered true.
Array An empty array is considered false. Any other array (even an associative array with no values) is considered true.
Object Any object is considered true.
For example...
Bool::val(""); // returns (bool) false Bool::val(true); // returns (bool) true Bool::val(0); // returns (bool) false Bool::val(0.0); // returns (bool) false Bool::val('0'); // returns (bool) false Bool::val('abc'); // returns (bool) true Bool::val('true'); // returns (bool) true Bool::val('on'); // returns (bool) true Bool::val('yes'); // returns (bool) true Bool::val('off'); // returns (bool) false Bool::val([]); // returns (bool) false Bool::val([1, 2]); // returns (bool) true Bool::val(new StdClass()); // returns (bool) true

docblock.description: The file for the directory (aka, "dir") class
The directory (aka, "dir") class
Returns a relative path (aka, "rel") from an absolute path (aka, "abs")

tag.name: return
tag.description: the relative path (e.g., 'folder') or false on failure

docblock.description: Copies files or directory to the filesystem
docblock.long-description:
PHP's native copy() function only copies files, not directories. I will recursively copy a directory and all of its files and sub-directories.
If the $destination exists, I will overwrite any existing files with the corresponding file in the $source directory.
If $destination does not exist, and $mode is set to false I will throw an InvalidArgumentException. If $mode is an integer (or omitted), I attempt to create the destination directory. I will recursively create destination directories as needed.
To copy a file, use PHP's native copy() method.

tag.name: param
tag.description:
the mode of the destination directory as an

octal number with a leading zero (ignored on Windows) (optional; if
omitted, defaults to 0777, the widest possible access) (set to false to
throw an exception if the destination directory does not exist)

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $mode is not an integer or false

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $source does not exist or is not a directory

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $destination does not exist or it could not be created successfully

docblock.description: Alias for Dir::copy() method
Deletes a non-empty directory and its sub-directories
docblock.long-description: PHP's native rmdir() function requires the directory to be empty. I'll recursively delete a directory's files and sub-directories. BE CAREFUL! Use the $container argument to be safe.

tag.name: param
tag.description: the path of the directory to remove

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if $directory is not a valid directory path

docblock.description: Alias for Dir::remove() method
